pageData.text: In this investigation, you will investigate the concepts of <button class='glossary-text'>heat</button> transfer and <button class='glossary-text'>calorimetry</button>. You will calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>specific heat</button> of various solids and compare the results to accepted values.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: Heat Capacity of the Calorimeter - 30 minutes 
Activity 2: Specific Heat of Four Solids - 100 minutes

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Specific Heat of Solids

text: Analyze and interpret the thermal properties of matter, including <button class='glossary-text'>specific heats</button>.
Describe the relationship between <button class='glossary-text'>temperature</button> and molecular motion and <button class='glossary-text'>heat</button> transfer.

pageData.text: “ islands” are urban areas where buildings, roads, and other infrastructure absorb the sun’s energy more than natural landscapes. The EPA reported that heat islands are 1–7°F higher in daytime and nighttime 2–5°F higher, as compared to the in the surrounding natural landscapes1. Different building materials and structures such as rooftops, streets, and sidewalks, for example, absorb heat differently. It is estimated that on a 91°F summer day, conventional roofing materials are up to 60°F warmer than the air temperature.

Heat islands have an increased electricity demand for air conditioning. Depending on the materials and location, the energy demand for every increase of 2°F is 1-9%. This increase in energy demand is also associated with an increase in carbon dioxide and pollutant emissions. There are many different strategies that urban areas can employ to lower the amount of heat absorbed. These include planting trees, including green spaces in urban planning, rooftop gardens, and using materials that reflect sunlight and heat away from buildings, streets, and sidewalks.

1Heat Islands. (2022). Learn About Heat Islands. EPA.
https://www.epa.gov/heatislands/learn-about-heat-islands#_ftn1

pageData.altText: An aerial view of a sprawling city.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Heat</button> is thermal energy caused by the movement of atoms and molecules. Atoms and molecules are in constant motion independent of the state of matter. This is easy to visualize for both gaseous and liquid phases, but not as easy for solids. Nevertheless, the atoms in a solid remain in vibration despite being in a fixed position (more or less) relative to each other.

When materials of differing <button class='glossary-text'>temperatures</button> touch, heat is transferred by means of <button class='glossary-text'>conduction</button>. The higher energy atoms impart energy to the lower energy ones through collisions and energetic free electron movement. Just like a metal rod with one end being held in a flame, the energy at the hot end eventually travels down the length of the rod and burns the hand holding it. This bulk motion of energy down the rod is solely the result of interactions between energy-disparate adjacent atoms. In this investigation, heat will conduct from boiling water to the metal cylinder, thereby heating the metal to the same temperature as the boiling water. The hot metal will then be put into room temperature water where it will heat that water through the process of conduction as well.

, cs, is an of materials and is defined as the amount of energy required to raise the temperature of 1 g of material by 1 °C. For example, water has a specific heat of 4.184 J/g °C. That is, 4.184 J of energy is required to raise the temperature of 1 g of water by 1 °C. The relationship between energy (q ), specific heat (cs), mass (m ), ands temperature (T ) is shown in Equation 1.

pageData.altText: Equation 1: q equals m integral begin sup T f end sup begin sub T i end sub C sub s d T

pageData.text: The of solids typically shows a substantial temperature dependence. As temperature decreases, its value decreases non-linearly and approaches 0 near 0 K. For most solids, it reaches a maximum near 500 K with a value around 25 J/mol·K. This phenomenon is known as the DuLong-Petit law. This value is on the molar basis and not the mass basis as is the case with specific heat. In this investigation, you will assume the value of cs at 25 °C as the specific heat for the materials through the temperature ranges realized in this investigation. Assuming that there is a constant specific heat value, Equation 1 can be simplified into Equation 2.

pageData.altText: Equation 2: q equals c sub s times m times delta T

pageData.text: Where q is energy, cs is specific heat, m is mass, and ΔT is the change in temperature
(ΔT = Tfinal - Tinitial)

pageData.question: Copper has a specific heat of 0.39 J/g °C. How much heat must be added in order to raise a 5.0 g copper block by 10 °C?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text:
q = cs • m • ΔT
q=  energy = ?
cs =  specific heat = 0.39 J/g °C
m =  mass = 5.0 g
ΔT  =  change in temperature = 10 °C
q  =  (0.39 J/g °C)(5.0 g)(10 °C)
q  = 19.5 J

pageData.question: Aluminum has a specific heat of 0.9 J/g °C. How much heat must be added in order to raise a 10 g aluminum block by 10 °C?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text:
q = cs • m • ΔT
q= energy = ?
cs = specific heat = 0.9 J/g °C
m = mass = 10.0 g
ΔT = change in temperature = 10 °C
q = (0.9 J/g °C)(10.0 g)(10 °C)
q = 90 J

q = cs • m • ΔT
q = energy
cs = specific heat
m = mass
ΔT  = change in temperature

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Calorimetry</button> is the method of measuring the amount of <button class='glossary-text'>heat</button> transfer within a closed system. The device in these types of investigations is named a <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button>. One critical design element of all calorimeters is that it must be insulated so that energy may not enter or exit the calorimeter’s system. This investigation will employ a rudimentary form of a calorimeter with a test tube, some paper towels, and a cup.

Since this calorimeter is overly simplistic, there will be energy gained by the calorimeter during the process of the hot metal and the room water achieving thermal equilibrium.In this investigation, the calorimeter contains a known mass of water at a known temperature. Then, solid cylinders at the temperature of boiling water are added to the calorimeter. Finally, the resulting temperature in the calorimeter is measured. When the hot solid is placed in the calorimeter, it transfers energy to the water and calorimeter conductively until the entire system establishes thermal equilibrium. Since negligible mechanical work is done in the process, the energy that leaves the metal is the same as the energy gained by the water and by the calorimeter. Energetically, this is expressed in Equation 3.

pageData.altText: Equation 3: q sub water plus q sub calorimeter equals minus sign q sub solid

pageData.text: Since the solid loses energy in this investigation, it is a negative quantity. Substituting Equation 2 into Equation 3 produces Equation 4.

pageData.altText: Equation 4: c sub s water times m sub water times delta T sub water plus q sub calorimeter equals minus begin paren c sub s solid times m sub solid times delta T sub solid end paren

pageData.text: Using this equation, the of the solid, cs solid, can be calculated.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of activity 1 of this investigation. Before beginning, you will assemble the calorimeter. In activity1, you will add cold water to the calorimeter and record its initial temperature. Then, you will add hot water to the graduated cylinder and record its initial temperature. Next, you will add the hot water to the cold water and record the temperature every minute for 10 minutes. Then, you will repeat the experiment for a total of 2 trials. Next, you will graph temperature versus time. Then, you will calculate the temperature difference, the energy lost to the calorimeter and the average heat capacity of the calorimeter. Finally, you will proceed to activity 2.

A map of the procedural workflow of activity 2 of this investigation. After completing activity 1, in activity 2, you will heat boiling water and measure its temperature. Then, you will measure the mass of the metal cylinder and add it to the boiling water. Next, you will measure the mass of the water and add it to the calorimeter. Then, you will measure the initial temperature of the water. Next, you will add the metal cylinder to the water in the calorimeter. Then, you will record the final temperature of the water. You will repeat this for two trials which each of the metal cylinders. Finally, you will calculate the average specific heat of each metal and the percent error of the specific heat of each metal.

pageData.text: Read all instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practice, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area thoroughly with soap a water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Copper has a specific heat of 0.39 J/g °C. If 1000 J was added to a 7.5 g copper block at 20 °C, what would be the final temperature of the block?
Aluminum has a specific heat of 0.9 J/g °C. If 500 J was added to a 2.5 g aluminum block at 50°C, what would be the final temperature of the block?
If 50 g of water in a calorimeter rises to 37 °C after absorbing 400 J of energy, what was the original temperature? The specific heat of water is 4.184 J/g °C.
100 g of water in a calorimeter drops 15 °C after 500 g of an unknown material is added. If the unknown material’s specific heat is 0.50 J/g °C, how many degrees did its temperature raise?

A liter bottle of cold water at 10 °C sits in the hot sun and absorbs 80,000 J of heat. What is the water’s final temperature? The density of water is 1.0 g/mL and water’s specific heat is 4.184 J/g °C.

A liter bottle of water at 21 °C sits outside on a cold day and loses 25,000 J of energy. What is the water’s final temperature? The density of water is 1.0 g/mL and water’s specific heat is 4.184 J/g °C.
If 50 g of water at 80 °C is added to 50 g of water at 20°C, what is the final temperature of the 100 g of water?
What item is needed to complete this investigation, but is not supplied?

Read through the procedure.
Clear a work area, and gather the needed materials.
Create a using one of the foam cups, paper or dish towels, and the test tube as shown in Figure 1 and Figure 2.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: view from above of a foam cup with a paper towel inside with a glass test tube placed next to the cup
Figure 2: foam cup with a paper towel stuffed inside with a glass test tub sitting upright inside the cup

pageData.text: Cut a piece of cardstock or cardboard that will fit over the top of the coffee cup, and cut a hole in the center to fit the test tube.

In Activity 1, you will calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>heat capacity</button> of the <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button> by mixing hot and cold water in the calorimeter and determining the energy lost to the calorimeter.

pages.title: Heat Capacity of the Calorimeter (15 steps)
pages.pageTitle: Heat Capacity of the Calorimeter (15 steps)

pageData.text: Measure 30 mL of water with a graduated cylinder and pour into the test tube of the <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button>. This is going to be referred to as the “cold” water.
Stir the water with the thermometer until the is constant, and record it as the initial temperature of the cold water, Tc, in Data Table 1.
Fill a foam cup halfway with the hottest tap water you can collect.
Take the temperature of the tap water. If the temperature is less than 80 ℃, <button class='glossary-text'>heat</button> in a microwave in short bursts until it is at least 80 ℃.

Dispense 30 mL of the “hot” water into a graduated cylinder. Place a thermometer in the cylinder and gently stir to get a constant reading. The temperature should be 75–80 ℃. Record this initial temperature of the hot water, Th, in Data Table 1.
Quickly pour the 30 mL of hot water into the test tube with the cold water and start a timer.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Gently stir the mixed water with the thermometer and record the temperature at 1 minute and then at 1-minute intervals for 10 minutes. Record this data into Data Table 2 under the “Trial 1” column.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Discard the water, dry the test tube with a paper towel, and put it back into the calorimeter assembly.
Repeat this activity, collecting a second set of data. Record the data in Data Table 2 under the “Trial 2” column.
Create a spreadsheet and graph for the temperature versus time data.
Calculate the linear trend line and use the y-intercept to find the temperature at time zero, T0 when the two volumes of water are mixed. Record this value in Data Table 1.

Subtract the y-intercept temperature from the theoretical temperature upon mixing. This should be a negative number. The negative sign denotes that the energy is leaving the system and entering the calorimeter. If it is not negative, please repeat Steps 1–9 to obtain new data. Record the absolute value of this temperature difference in Data Table 1.

Using the total mass of water for the investigation (60 g), the <button class='glossary-text'>specific heat</button> of water (4.184 J/g ℃), and this temperature difference, calculate the energy lost to the calorimeter.
Finally, calculate the temperature difference between Tc and T0. Record this value in Data Table 1.
Divide the energy lost to the calorimeter by this temperature change to calculate Ccal. Record this value in Data Table 1.

In Activity 2, you will calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>specific heat</button> of 4 different metals by adding them to the <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button> and observing the <button class='glossary-text'>temperature</button> change of the water. You will then calculate the percent error by comparing the actual and experimental <button class='glossary-text'>heat</button> capacities.

pages.title: Specific Heat of Four Solids (19 steps)
pages.pageTitle: Specific Heat of Four Solids (19 steps)

pageData.text: Pour tap water into the pot to about half full, and set on the stove.
water to boiling. Measure of the boiling water. You will assume the metal’s initial temperature, Tinitial solid, to be equal to that temperature. Record this value in Data Table 3.
Turn on the electronic balance, tare it, and measure the mass of the aluminum cylinder. Record this mass, msolid, in Data Table 3.
Gently set the metal into the heating pot of water.
Place the other foam cup on the balance and tare. Pour tap water into the cup until approximately 30 g (1 oz) of water is dispensed. Record the actual mass, mwater, in Data Table 3.
Carefully pour all of that water into the test tube and set into the <button class='glossary-text'>calorimeter</button>. Should you lose any water in the transfer, please empty and repeat Step 5.
Place the thermometer into the test tube and measure the temperature. Record this temperature, Tinitial water, in Data Table 3.

Once the water in the pot has been boiling for approximately 2 minutes, turn the stovetop heat off. Use kitchen tongs to carefully transfer the metal cylinder to the calorimeter. It is best to hold the calorimeter at an angle when the metal is dropped into it to minimize any water loss.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Once the metal cylinder is in the calorimeter, set it flat on the table, and insert the thermometer.

Slowly move the calorimeter in a small circular pattern in order to swirl the water inside. Note the increasing temperature inside the calorimeter until it peaks, which should occur within a minute. Record that temperature, Tfinal, for both the water and the metal in Data Table 3.
Remove the metal cylinder from the calorimeter and discard the water. Dry the inside of the calorimeter as well as possible.
Repeat Steps 2–11 for a second trial of the aluminum cylinder.
Repeat Steps 2–12 for the brass cylinder. Record all data into Data Table 4.
Repeat Steps 2–12 for the steel cylinder. Record all data into Data Table 5.
Repeat Steps 2–12 for the copper cylinder. Record all data into Data Table 6.
For each data set, calculate the change in temperature using the formula ΔT = Tfinal - Tinitial. Please note that ΔT will be positive for water and negative for the metal.
For each data set, calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>specific heat</button> of the metal for each trial by using Equation 4.
For each data set, calculate the average of the two trials.
For each data set, calculate the percent error by using Equation 5.

pageData.altText: Equation 5: percent error equals begin absolute value begin fraction c sub s begin paren actual end paren minus sign c sub s begin paren experimental average end paren over c sub s begin paren actual end paren end fraction end absolute value times 100 percent

pageData.text: Return the materials to the equipment kit and clean the area.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

text: When the metal cylinder transfers its energy to the water in the calorimeter, mechanical work is done since the metal will contract upon cooling. Prove that this work is truly negligible in comparison to the energy transferred for each of the materials used in this experiment. Since the pressure of the system is constant, W = P•ΔV. For the metals, ΔV = β •V•ΔT. Use standard atmospheric pressure, 1.103 N/m2 in your calculations and the expansion coefficients in the table below.

header.text: Volume Expansion Coefficient (*10-6 /°C)

text: Using your experimentally determined specific heat for aluminum and copper, calculate the heat capacity for each elemental material on a per mole basis. Explain the underlying atomic and molecular principles that cause them to be comparable.

pageData.text: In order for your instructor to be able to open your video links, please select the "Save as PDF" option rather than "Print to PDF".

pageData.content: Equation 2. Specific heat capacity equation (assuming constant specific heat)
pageData.altText: Equation 2: q equals c sub s times m times delta T

pageData.content: Equation 3. Energy lost by metal is equal to energy gained by water and calorimeter
pageData.altText: Equation 3: q sub water plus q sub calorimeter equals minus sign q sub solid

pageData.content: Equation 4. Specific heat capacity equation for calorimeter
pageData.altText: Equation 4: c sub s water times m sub water times delta T sub water plus q sub calorimeter equals minus begin paren c sub s solid times m sub solid times delta T sub solid end paren

A map of the procedural workflow of activity 1 of this investigation. Before beginning, you will assemble the calorimeter. In activity1, you will add cold water to the calorimeter and record its initial temperature. Then, you will add hot water to the graduated cylinder and record its initial temperature. Next, you will add the hot water to the cold water and record the temperature every minute for 10 minutes. Then, you will repeat the experiment for a total of 2 trials. Next, you will graph temperature versus time. Then, you will calculate the temperature difference, the energy lost to the calorimeter and the average heat capacity of the calorimeter. Finally, you will proceed to activity 2.

A map of the procedural workflow of activity 2 of this investigation. After completing activity 1, in activity 2, you will heat boiling water and measure its temperature. Then, you will measure the mass of the metal cylinder and add it to the boiling water. Next, you will measure the mass of the water and add it to the calorimeter. Then, you will measure the initial temperature of the water. Next, you will add the metal cylinder to the water in the calorimeter. Then, you will record the final temperature of the water. You will repeat this for two trials which each of the metal cylinders. Finally, you will calculate the average specific heat of each metal and the percent error of the specific heat of each metal.

data.title: Calorimeter
data.content: An apparatus for measuring the amount of heat invovled in a chemical reaction or other process

data.title: Calorimetry
data.content: The method of measuring the amount of heat transfer within a closed system

data.title: Conduction
data.content: The transfer of heat between 2 objects that are physically touching

data.title: Heat
data.content: Thermal energy caused by the movement of atoms and molecules

data.title: Heat capacity
data.content: The number of heat units needed to raise the temperature of a body by one degree

data.title: Intensive property
data.content: A physical property that does not depend on the amount, size, or shape of the substance

data.title: Specific heat (cs)
data.content: The amount of heat energy necessary to raise the temperature of 1 gram by 1 °Ct

data.title: Temperature (T)
data.content: A measurement of the average speed of the molecules of gas and is expressed in units of Kelvin (K)
